Constitutive Judgement
My second ‚Äòstep back‚Äô considers the kind of judgement an
agent makes, when they decide to adopt an AP. Look at
these three cases:
(1) I watch the road while driving. I don‚Äôt want to crash.
(2) I‚Äôm careful with my speech at work. My boss fires
anyone who speaks imprecisely.
2
(3) I‚Äôve decided to be more honest with friends. I recently
opened up to a friend about a struggle I‚Äôm having.
Since then, the relationship feels more intimate, and
stronger; it‚Äôs easier for me to think about what to say;
my friend is unexpectedly helpful.
In all three examples, the agent notes some benefits of adopt-
ing an AP ùëé in a context ùëê‚Äîbenefits like staying alive, keep-
ing my job, and having helpful friends. And in each case,
this leads to a decision to adopt it.
But, in the first two examples, those benefits come together
to make the case that doing ùëé in ùëê is functional, necessary,
prudent, or expedient. The judgement is based on expected
costs and benefits, much as a rational choice theorist would
hope. I‚Äôll call this an instrumental judgement.
In (3), the benefits become supporting evidence for a much
larger claim: that honesty with friends is constitutive of
good relationships11, or at least naturally goes together with
them. The benefits suggest that honesty is going to be part
of any relationship I want to build, or is part of the person I
want to be‚Äînot just that it‚Äôs functional in achieving certain
ends. It‚Äôs a part-whole claim, or a claim to synergy, not a
claim about cause and effect.
I‚Äôll call this a constitutive judgement. To make one, we
ask ourselves questions like: are Xs impossible without Ys?
Are Xs without Ys in some way lesser? Are there kinds of
wholeness that emerge only when an X has a Y? Note: the
evidence that goes into these questions looks a lot like costs
and benefits (additional kinds of wholeness, etc)! So the
raw materials for this judgement are similar, but instead of
building an expected value, we build a more general conclu-
sion.
Why do we make constitutive judgements, instead of doing
a cost-benefit analysis for everything? Other authors have
marked out a role for constitutive judgements in moral rea-
soning,12 higher-order desires,13 self-understanding,14 and
identifying natural kinds,15 but there‚Äôs also a case to be
made from bounded rationality:16 constitutive judgements
are cognitively eÔ¨Äicient. Instead of asking each time we have
an X, whether we should also have an Y, we ask up-front if
Xs and Ys belong together. If we think so, we put Ys in our
Xs without considering each case.
Anyways, both kinds of judgement can have errors, and
are subject to reconsideration. Instrumental judgements
are more delicate, because they depend on a more-or-less
complete accounting of costs, benefits, and eÔ¨Äicacy. For
constitutive judgements, you don‚Äôt need such a complete
accounting: if the benefits you‚Äôve already noticed line up
nicely, you can take them as evidence of a synergy or whole-
ness. You‚Äôll reconsider your judgement only if you start to
think you got the overall pattern wrong.
This gives us a way to tell APs resulting from a constitu-
tive judgements (CAPs) from those adopted instrumentally
(IAPs). Say an agent uses AP ùëé in context ùëê.
11Good relationships for this agent, at least.
12Rawls, A Theory of Justice.
13Taylor, ‚Äú4 What Is Human Agency?‚Äù
14Velleman, Practical Reflection.
15Boyd, ‚ÄúHow to Be a Moral Realist.‚Äù
16Following Simon, ‚ÄúA Behavioral Model of Rational Choice‚Äù; Gib-
son, The Senses Considered as Perceptual Systems; and Bratman,
Intention, Plans, and Practical Reason.
First, you can ask her: why is ùëé wise in ùëê? Does she gives a
small number of reasons, pointing towards one state of the
world, ùë†, that she‚Äôs working to achieve, maintain, or ensure
(such as ‚Äòstaying alive,‚Äô or ‚Äòkeeping her job‚Äô)? Or does she
gives diffuse, unconnected reasons, and sense she‚Äôs only just
begun discovering the benefits of ùëé in ùëê?
Second, do the given reasons seem to capture her full ra-
tionale? If so, it‚Äôs likely an IAP. To test this, ask her how
she‚Äôd feel if they were taken out of consideration (e.g., if
she discovered she‚Äôd crash anyways, that her speech had no
bearing on whether she‚Äôd be fired, or that, without opening
up to friends, she could magically get the same benefits):
Would she select a different AP for ùëê and consider herself
better off, free to focus on something else? Similarly, would
she consider it a net gain if she could clone herself, and
have the clone handle doing ùëé in ùëê? Or otherwise automate
the achievement of ùë†? Or‚Äîon the other hand‚Äîwould she
reserve for herself the task of doing ùëé rather than give it to
the clone?
Finally, while doing ùëé, does she split her attention, putting
some attention on how ùë† is going, so that she can recon-
sider, if needed, the eÔ¨Äicacy of ùëé in achieving ùë†? Or is her
attention is wholly on ùëé, with no worry about what she‚Äôs
achieving/maintaining/ensuring?
Figure 2: Verifying CAPs
I‚Äôve found that these conditions almost always coincide. An
AP adopted for diffuse reasons will tend to have someone‚Äôs
whole attention, and they‚Äôll be resistant to automating it.
A strong sign it‚Äôs a CAP

Let me analyze this thoughtfully. You've shared some interesting observations about IAPs (Instrumental Attentional Policies) and raised important questions about their unconscious nature and relationship to meaning.

From reviewing both the document and your observations, I can synthesize a structured definition:

An IAP (Instrumental Attentional Policy) is:
1. A pattern of attention and behavior driven primarily by external pressures, anticipated consequences, or conditioned responses
2. Characterized by:
   - Focus on a specific, narrow outcome (staying alive, keeping a job)
   - Attention split between the action and monitoring its effectiveness
   - Willingness to automate or delegate if possible
   - Rationale based on clear cause-and-effect reasoning
   - Often accompanied by catastrophizing thoughts or anxiety
   - May operate unconsciously or become habitual over time

Rather than calling it a "not source of meaning," we might more accurately describe it as a "pressure-response pattern" or "instrumental behavior loop." The key distinction is that IAPs:

1. Are maintained by their consequences rather than their inherent value
2. Often persist through negative reinforcement (avoiding bad outcomes) rather than positive alignment with values
3. Can become disconnected from their original purpose, continuing through momentum or habit
4. May start from a meaningful intention (CAP) but degrade into mechanical performance over time

This helps explain why IAPs often feel empty or draining - they're not aligned with deeper values or sources of meaning, but rather with avoiding negative outcomes or maintaining status quo. They represent what you aptly called "forces of stasis" - patterns that keep us in motion but don't necessarily move us toward what we find meaningful.

Would you like me to elaborate on any particular aspect of this definition or explore how it might be applied to identify and understand IAPs in practice?
